objects.name: Directions
objects.string:
Hello and welcome to the SG Institute of Juice
Enjoy your time at the game feel test range.
V. 1.0
(LMouse): Fire
(RMouse): Move
Consult the event comments to learn more.

events.comment:
Hi There

This is a collection of small effects, tricks and general tips for making your game feel better. I'll also briefly touch on subjects like camera movement and sound design so you have a pretty broad tutorial example at hand.

Please note that this is an intermediate tutorial. It won't explain every single step to make these things, rather you are supposed to look at and coppy the events/objects and figure some stuff out yourself. You'll need some understanding of how GDev works in general and how variables and object variables work in particular. If you are new to GDevelop you should do other tutorials first.

Many of the systems here work with game states, so things like screenshake etc have 
a) events that can initialize them from anywhere in the game and 
b) events that govern their behavior once initialised.

Also I'd like to note that, while I uses these technique in and action game context, they are applicable to nearly any type of games. If you look at recent entries for deck builders or strategy games you'll see at least some of the techniques used. And speaking of reference games: I tried to mention examples of games that use these techniques to good effect as often as possible. 

For further reference on why this stuff is important I recommend Jan Willem Nijmans video on the topic: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AJdEqssNZ-U

- Comments always refer to the event that comes bellow them.
- Comment colors indicate categories:
Yellow - General
Orange - VFX
Blue - SFX
Red - Camera
Just initialising the scene here, nothing to see, move along to the juicy bits ;)
Activate this to hide cam and direction helper.

Let's start with some camera work. Here we use our players move state to change how the camera tracks the player.

Note that we work with a "cam_target" object that we later focus the camera on. Doing this instead of focusing directly on the player entity gives us more freedom for handling camera movement. For example you can now apply forces or movement tweens to your camera. You'll generally want to hide that cam_target, I just left it visible for demonstration sake.

If the player does not move then the cam_target slowly lerps to the player position. Using lerp in camera movement is almost always a good idea. Even if you want a super snappy camera you might still want to use a very faint lerp. Your own eyesight and focus is lerped too and a camera that targets the player rigidly and perfectly will usually feel artificial and off.

The second event works pretty much the same, but uses a point on another helper object that tracks the players movement direction. This way we can have the camera trail ahead while the player moves. Look at the ui_move_direction animation for reference. You can get a lot of different results using helper objects, points and different lerps, going way beyond a camera that just tracks the player.

Reference: Luftrausers, SYNTHETIK

---Angle Snapping on Rotating Pixelart---

Note that we decrease the rotation of the weapon by a factor, then round it and multiply it up again with the same factor. This has it "snap" to fixed angle intervals. In some circumstances this can make your art look better since the object does not constantly rotate even on the slightest movement. Especially advisable for when you rotate pixel art. You can use smaller round intervals to make the effect less noticeable.

Reference: Enter the Gungen, Nuclear Throne

---Slight General Randomization---

Also note that we apply a lot of small randomizations in many places (shots aren't perfectly accurate, have slight speed variations, trail animations starts at random frames, casings eject on slightly random angles).  In a game, imperfection is perfection, because actual perfection drops the facade.  Generally the more regular and static your game behaves the more artificial it appears, so in most cases you want your game to have these slight inaccuracies everywhere.  Even the slightest randomization will still have this effect, even if you think it's not even notieceable.

---Cam Recoil---

Cam recoil can reinforce powerful movement and forces. You can use distance conditions on your cam_target to keep the effect in check. Both moving and limiting the camera this way isn't really possible without a cam_target object.

Reference: Nuclear Throne

---Small VFX---

Just adding small VFX to pretty much any action that occurs ingame can go a long way for making it more lively.

Mirror randomization can be an efficient way to give variance to your VFX. In this example we only have a single muzzle flash sprite but since it is asymmetrical and only shows for a few frame we can have it appear more varied by just mirroring it randomly.

---Shot Trail---

This creates an animated shot trail that follows your shot to the target. We'll see how it is handled further down.

Reference: Enter the Gungeon

---Random Falling Objects, Permanence and Mass Object Fade Out---

Here we create casing from our weapon that fall to the ground and remain in the level.
But first we do a opacity reduction to slowly fade out any casings that where previously spawned. You can adjust this to your liking and make more complex despawn behaviors with object variables.

These casings are just one example of how your action can permanently affect your environment. Overall this makes the game world more tangible. Just make sure you keep it efficient and manage your objects. The actual casing removal happens further down.

Reference: Hotline Miami
Enable this to trigger screenshake on firing.

--Dynamic Ambient Mix--

Here we explore a couple very basic sound design tweaks. First note that we change the ambiance volume (applied elsewhere to the levels ambient noise) to give more room to your weapon sound. Generally you want to mix down less important things to draw more attention to relevant actions, player and enemy sound in particular. The ambiance fades in quickly after each shot.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--SFX Variances---

We also randomize the weapon sound on each shot. This is another case where slight variants make things more tangible and feel more real, regardless if this is actually realistic. Most of all this prevents sounds from tiring out your ears.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--Dynamic SFX Vol---

Dynamic volume reduction on repetitive sound is another way to prevent sounds from getting obtrusive. On weapons that can also help emphasizing the first shot/opening attack. 

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--Dynamic SFX Pitch---

Here we increase a pitch variable each time a fire sound is played. This way we give feedback on longer attack actions and overall make the action feel less samy again.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

--Sound Layering---

Here we fade in another sound that combines with our main gun sound after the max pitch is reached. You can use this kind of layering to all kinds of ends (for when players run out of ammo for example, or to layer in echo in open spaces etc). 

The clang sound also uses a different kind of variance where it randomizes its pitch each time it is played. This way you can get more mileage out of sounds even if you only have a single variant of it on file.

Reference: Any game that had a sound designer.

---Dynamic Sound Reset---

In this example we reset everything with the same event, but you might want to differentiate this more once you do a lot of sound handling.

--Ambiance Vol Reset---

This brings back your ambiance after it has been ducked.

---Shot Trail Scaling---

Here we handle our shot trail. Note that the factor we divide the trail by is shorter than the actual sprite. The trail has a lot of glow but the actual trail is only 96px long. Also look at the vfx_shot_trail animation and note that the origin/center is at the point where the trail physically starts, since that is the position we want it to extend from.

Using the linked object conditions comes with the advantage that the trail will stop growing as soon as the shot is removed, but you might want to adjust that if you need different behaviors.

With good sprites you can make this quite a nice effect, but there are limits due to the fact that this uses stretching in order to scale the trail. There might be a better method to do this in future version of GDevelop.

---Casing Handling---

This makes casings hit the ground and stop moving. The random angle further adds to the effect and since it only does a position check you can do it on a lot of objects before it becomes taxing.

---Triggering Hitlag---

This initializes hitlag. 0.03 effectively means 0.3 seconds of slowdown, since the hitlag duration is itself affected by the slowdown. 0.3 is very heavy hitlag, you'll want to tune this to your preference and like many things here, you'll probably want to enable the player to change the effects in your game's options.

Like screenshake, hitlag can be made to overwrite existing hitlag with = and can be made to add to existing lag with +. You might again need limiters as conditions or your additive hitlag might turn into full on slowmo if triggered rapidly.

Reference: Early arcade fighting games, Dead Cells

---Handling Hitlag---

If your game uses variable times scale you need to make sure that the hitlag resets you scale to a variable instead. Here we always reset the time scale to 1 after the effect wears off.

I prefer a 90% slowdown to total hit stop, but your mileage may vary. Using slowdown has the added benefit that you can use the hitlag system to trigger general slow motion effects too.

Reference: SUPER HOT

---Triggering Hitflash---

This changes an objects color on hit and the variable affects how long it will "flash" in that color. Classic hitflashing would make the object turn white, you can achieve this using the blink extension.

Reference: Hollow Knight

---Hitflash Reseting---

This causes objects to reset to their normal color once they run out of hitflash time. If you regularly recolor your objects with events ingame you'll need to give them a color variable to reset to, otherwise the hitlag reset will overwrite the color you gave them via other events.

---Triggering Jelly Wobble---

This whole effect can probably also achieved using the tween behavior on objects. In a way the following showcases what tweens actually do behind the scenes. Making these behaviors yourself might give you more gradual control in some areas.

This makes objects wobble as if made of jelly. We handle that in detail further down. Note that we also change the object scale here to properly initialize the jelly wobbling.

---Jelly Wobble Handling---

I don't fully understand how this works (saw this in another non-GDev tutorial once) but essentially we have a variable that oscillates (?) due to the lerp (?!?) and that is applied to x-scale directly and y-scale invertedly (?!?!?). Anyway, it just works, so copy that code and tinker till the result fits. :D 

Objects that are jelly scaled need to have their own obj_scale_lerp variable between 1 and >0. This affects how rigidly the object wobbles, higher values make it wobble less and faster basically.

Note that we did a + to the width here, so how you change the object scale when initializing the wobbling also affects how it subsequently executes. I generally go with something like 1.5 for x and 0.5 for y. You don't want to go too low on your y or too high on your x or the wobbly will execute with a lot of 0 scaling.
The is_squishy variable affects how long the object is considered for wobbling independent from whether the effect is still discernible.

---Small VFX---

Just adding small animated VFX to pretty much any action that occurs ingame can go a long way for making it more lively. Make some of these effects permanent or long lasting further adds to the "realness" of your world. Here we use seperate evenst to do three things:

1. We spawn a small impact where the shot hit.
2. We spawn a floor effect that remains in the scene and uses the same "fade out exisiting objects" as our casing system.
3. We also re-use our casing system to spawn some particles that fly off the target, because we are lazy and lazy is efficient.

These are just a few examples of what you can do. Generally the more individually differentiated VFX you add to a thing the more interesting but also pronounced it becomes. Further note that some of these VFX are affected by our attack angle. VFX reacting to their source this way will add to their plausibility.

---Spawning Float Text---

here we spawn imaginary damage numbers to give more feedback on attacks. We use a lot of forces here to make the text move with the attack, away from the target and also continuously downwards as if affected by gravity.

Reference: Pretty much every JRPG

---Spawning Float Text---

The is_new variable triggers some general text handling but you might want to handle this difference. Chances are that if your game uses float text, it'll use it a lot and everywhere, so you might want to streamline the actions that'll affect every float text.

Reference: Pretty much every JRPG

---Spawning Float Text---

Here we dynamically change our float text to a custom behavior if our attacks crit. Note the movement change and is_new switch off, making the text rise up instead of being affected by the usual downwards text gravity.

Reference: Pretty much every JRPG

--Float Text Handling---

We use a oppacity variable to both have the text fade out and be removed once it reaches zero, but you can handle this as you see fit.
Here we fiddle with our texts size to position it centered correctly at the point we spawned it and give it some downward gravity too.
Whether you want to do this scale down also depends on your preference. Since GDev text uses top left as origin the scaling wont work so nicely on larger text.

---Objects/Text Flashing Through Multiple Colors--

And lastly we have an event that makes a text go through a set of colors. You can adjust variables and colors to change frequency and the like. Introduce a flash_count variable and you can have it stop flashing after a set number of executions. You can also use less and more colors by changing the point at which it resets _progress to 0. Additional is_flashy_x states in objects can trigger flashes of different if you define them. They can use the same flash_timer/flash/progress.

This effect can easily be applied to sprites too, but note that text color and sprite color are changed with different actions.
You'd use the below events if you want to add additional colors to the flashing. Moving the _flash_progress = 0 to the end is also required to make this work.

I hope these examples where usefull. Feel free to experiment with the events and copy anything you want to use.

If you want to see these techniques in actions you can check out my free games on 
itch.io https://sleeper-games.itch.io/ 
or my comercial stuff on Steam 
https://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Sleeper%20Games

You can also find me on Twitter:
https://twitter.com/Sleeper_Games

Cheers!
Stefan - Sleeper Games

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: FireBullet
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating.
description: This extension allows objects to fire bullets.
It handles:
- cooldown between shots
- firing multiple bullets at a time
- ammo management
- overheat
[A simplified version](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fire-bullet) of the top-down twin-stick shooter example allows to check it out.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Fire bullets, manage ammo, reloading, and overheating.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: FireBullet

events.comment: Creators can use the "FireBullet" action multiple times in a frame and it will be counted as a single "shot".
Subtract 1 from ammo (if not unlimited ammo)
Increase heat (if needed)
Check if this caused overheat
Detect when reload is completed
Only reload the amount of ammo available

events.name: Reduce heat level (based on cooling rate)

eventsFunctions.description:
Fire bullets toward a position.

Each bullet is assigned variables for advanced object picking
- __FireBullet.BulletID, Unique number for every bullet created
- __FireBullet.BatchID, Unique number for all bullets created in the same frame
- __FireBullet.BatchOrderID, Unique number for each bullet in the same batch. Can be used to identify the position in the firing arc.
eventsFunctions.name: FireTowardPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Fire _PARAM4_ from _PARAM0_, at position _PARAM2_; _PARAM3_, toward position _PARAM5_;_PARAM6_ with speed _PARAM7_ px/s

events.name: Calculate the trajectory angle and use the "Fire bullets" action

parameters.description: X position, where to create the bullet
parameters.name: XPosition

parameters.description: Y position, where to create the bullet
parameters.name: YPosition

parameters.description: Speed of the bullet, in pixels per second
parameters.name: Speed

eventsFunctions.description:
Fire bullets in the direction of a given angle.

Each bullet is assigned variables for advanced object picking
- __FireBullet.BulletID, Unique number for every bullet created
- __FireBullet.BatchID, Unique number for all bullets created in the same frame
- __FireBullet.BatchOrderID, Unique number for each bullet in the same batch. Can be used to identify the position in the firing arc.
eventsFunctions.name: Fire
eventsFunctions.sentence: Fire _PARAM4_ from _PARAM0_, at position _PARAM2_; _PARAM3_, toward angle _PARAM5_ and speed _PARAM6_ px/s

events.comment: Move temp variable to the next angle a bullet will be sent

eventsFunctions.sentence: Fire a single bullet _PARAM4_ from _PARAM0_, at position _PARAM2_; _PARAM3_, with angle _PARAM5_ and speed _PARAM6_ px/s

events.comment: Create bullet
Move bullet
Add identifier variables (to enable advanced picking by users)
Rotate newly created bullet, if needed
Update statistics

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object. This action must be called after the object has moved for the frame.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCameraCloser
eventsFunctions.sentence: Move the camera closer to _PARAM0_

events.comment: The camera following is called with an action, the call from doStepPreEvents must be disabled to avoid to do it twice.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object.
eventsFunctions.name: DoMoveCameraCloser
eventsFunctions.sentence: Do move the camera closer _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

eventsFunctions.description: Delay the camera according to a maximum speed and catch up the delay.
eventsFunctions.name: WaitAndCatchUp
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delay the camera of _PARAM0_ during: _PARAM2_ seconds according to the maximum speed _PARAM3_;_PARAM4_ seconds and catch up in _PARAM5_ seconds

events.comment: Maybe the catch-up show be done in constant pixel speed instead of constant time speed.

parameters.description: Waiting maximum camera target speed X
parameters.name: WaitingSpeedXMax

parameters.description: Waiting maximum camera target speed Y
parameters.name: WaitingSpeedYMax

eventsFunctions.description: Update delayed position and delayed history. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateDelayedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update delayed position and delayed history of _PARAM0_

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

eventsFunctions.name: AddForecastHistoryPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Add the time:_PARAM2_ and position: _PARAM3_; _PARAM4_ to the forecast history of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful.
Keep at least 2 positions because no forecast can be done with less positions.

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition
eventsFunctions.sentence: Update forecasted position of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX)²)
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY)²)
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a² + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a² + 1)

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ratio between forecast time and the duration of the history. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ForecastTimeRatio

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: westboy31, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CameraShake
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
description: Shake layer cameras with translation, rotation and zoom.
- Short shaking can be used to give impact (explosion, hit)
- Shaking can go indefinitely to set an ambiance (engine vibration, earthquake, pulsing)
- Low frequency shaking allows to simulate slow moving objects (ship rocking back and forth)
- Setting amplitudes per layer make it possible to respect the parallax and give more depth
Release notes:
- Version 3.0.0
- No adaptation of the game events is needed.
- It fixes an issue when used with scrolling, the amplitude will feel bigger in this case.
- The shaking relies on noise which could feel a bit different.
- This extension can no longer do impulses. For this, another extension "Camera impulse" can be used.

events.comment: Step time counters.
Use user defined default values when there is no layer specific value set.

Shake the layer camera.
Save the camera displacement to revert it in onScenePostEvents.
Revert the shaking.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Shake camera on _PARAM3_ layer for _PARAM5_ seconds. Use an amplitude of _PARAM1_px on X axis and _PARAM2_px on Y axis, angle rotation amplitude _PARAM6_ degrees, and zoom amplitude _PARAM7_ percent.  Wait _PARAM8_ seconds between shakes. Keep shaking until stopped: _PARAM9_

inlineCode: * Create the manager of noise generators.
* Create a noise generator with a seed.
// Make the circle perimeter equals to the looping period
// to keep the same perceived frequency with or without looping.
noiseSum += noiseFunction(x * frequency, y * frequency, z * frequency, w * frequency) * amplitude;
A fast javascript implementation of simplex noise by Jonas Wagner
Based on a speed-improved simplex noise algorithm for 2D, 3D and 4D in Java.
Which is based on example code by Stefan Gustavson (stegu@itn.liu.se).
Better rank ordering method by Stefan Gustavson in 2012.
Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy
of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal
in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights
to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell
copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is
furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:
The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all
copies or substantial portions of the Software.

/** Deterministic simplex noise generator suitable for 2D, 3D and 4D spaces. */
* This involves some setup. You can save a few cpu cycles by reusing the same instance.
* @param {(() => number)|string|number} randomOrSeed A random number generator or a seed (string|number).
const random = typeof randomOrSeed == 'function' ? randomOrSeed : alea(randomOrSeed);
* Samples the noise field in 2 dimensions
let n0 = 0; // Noise contributions from the three corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y) * F2; // Hairy factor for 2D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y distances from the cell origin
// For the 2D case, the simplex shape is an equilateral triangle.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1; // Offsets for second (middle) corner of simplex in (i,j) coords
// A step of (1,0) in (i,j) means a step of (1-c,-c) in (x,y), and
// a step of (0,1) in (i,j) means a step of (-c,1-c) in (x,y), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G2; // Offsets for middle corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
const x2 = x0 - 1.0 + 2.0 * G2; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the three simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the three corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0); // (x,y) of grad3 used for 2D gradient
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1);
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to return values in the interval [-1,1].
* Samples the noise field in 3 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3; // Noise contributions from the four corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y + z) * F3; // Very nice and simple skew factor for 3D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z distances from the cell origin
// For the 3D case, the simplex shape is a slightly irregular tetrahedron.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1, k1; // Offsets for second corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
let i2, j2, k2; // Offsets for third corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
// A step of (1,0,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (1-c,-c,-c) in (x,y,z),
// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G3; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x3 = x0 - 1.0 + 3.0 * G3; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the four simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the four corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad3[gi0 + 2] * z0);
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1]]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad3[gi1 + 2] * z1);
const gi2 = permMod12[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2]]] * 3;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad3[gi2 + 2] * z2);
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad3[gi3] * x3 + grad3[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad3[gi3 + 2] * z3);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to stay just inside [-1,1]
* Samples the noise field in 4 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3, n4; // Noise contributions from the five corners
// Skew the (x,y,z,w) space to determine which cell of 24 simplices we're in
const s = (x + y + z + w) * F4; // Factor for 4D skewing
const t = (i + j + k + l) * G4; // Factor for 4D unskewing
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z,w) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z,w distances from the cell origin
// For the 4D case, the simplex is a 4D shape I won't even try to describe.
// To find out which of the 24 possible simplices we're in, we need to
// determine the magnitude ordering of x0, y0, z0 and w0.
// Six pair-wise comparisons are performed between each possible pair
// of the four coordinates, and the results are used to rank the numbers.
// simplex[c] is a 4-vector with the numbers 0, 1, 2 and 3 in some order.
// Many values of c will never occur, since e.g. x>y>z>w makes x<z, y<w and x<w
// impossible. Only the 24 indices which have non-zero entries make any sense.
// We use a thresholding to set the coordinates in turn from the largest magnitude.
// Rank 2 denotes the second largest coordinate.
// Rank 1 denotes the second smallest coordinate.
// The integer offsets for the second simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the third simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the fourth simplex corner
// The fifth corner has all coordinate offsets = 1, so no need to compute that.
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G4; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G4; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x3 = x0 - i3 + 3.0 * G4; // Offsets for fourth corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x4 = x0 - 1.0 + 4.0 * G4; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the five simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the five corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad4[gi0] * x0 + grad4[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad4[gi0 + 2] * z0 + grad4[gi0 + 3] * w0);
const gi1 = (perm[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1 + perm[ll + l1]]]] % 32) * 4;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]
* This is exported only for (internal) testing purposes.
* Do not rely on this export.
The ALEA PRNG and masher code used by simplex-noise.js
is based on code by Johannes Baagøe, modified by Jonas Wagner.
See alea.md for the full license.

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 2 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise2d

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 3 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise3d

eventsFunctions.description: Generate a number from 4 dimensional simplex noise.
eventsFunctions.name: Noise4d

eventsFunctions.description: Create a noise generator with default settings (frequency = 1,  octaves = 1, persistence = 0.5, lacunarity = 2).
eventsFunctions.name: Create
eventsFunctions.sentence: Create a noise generator named _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Delete a noise generator and loose its settings.
eventsFunctions.name: Delete
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delete _PARAM1_ noise generator

eventsFunctions.description: Delete all noise generators and loose their settings.
eventsFunctions.name: DeleteAll
eventsFunctions.sentence: Delete all noise generators

eventsFunctions.description: The seed is a number used to generate the random noise. Setting the same seed will result in the same random noise generation. It's for example useful to generate the same world, by saving this seed value and reusing it later to generate again a world.
eventsFunctions.name: SetSeed
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise seed to _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the looping period on X used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on X.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopPeriodX
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the looping period on X of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the looping period on Y used for noise generation. The noise will wrap-around on Y.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopPeriodY
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the looping period on Y of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the base frequency used for noise generation. A lower frequency will zoom in the noise.
eventsFunctions.name: SetFrequency
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise frequency of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the number of octaves used for noise generation. It can be seen as layers of noise with different zoom.
eventsFunctions.name: SetOctaves
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the number of noise octaves of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the persistence used for noise generation. At its default value "0.5", it halves the noise amplitude at each octave.
eventsFunctions.name: SetPersistence
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise persistence of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the lacunarity used for noise generation. At its default value "2", it doubles the frequency at each octave.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLacunarity
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the noise lacunarity of _PARAM2_: _PARAM1_

eventsFunctions.description: The seed used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Seed

eventsFunctions.description: The base frequency used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Frequency

eventsFunctions.description: The number of octaves used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Octaves

eventsFunctions.description: The persistence used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Persistence

eventsFunctions.description: The lacunarity used for noise generation.
eventsFunctions.name: Lacunarity
